description: From Late Middle English solar, from Latin sōlāris, from sōl (“sun”), from Proto-Indo-European *sóh₂wl̥ (“sun”).

entries.meaning: Of or pertaining to the sun; proceeding from the sun
(astrology, obsolete) Born under the predominant influence of the sun.
examples: and proud beside, as solar people are

entries.meaning: Measured by the progress or revolution of the sun in the ecliptic; as, the solar year.
Produced by the action of the sun, or peculiarly affected by its influence.

description: From Middle English solar, soler; from a conflation of Old English soler, solere (“raised platform; loft, upper room, upper part of a house, soler”), from Latin sōlārium; and Old English solor, salor (“residence, dwelling; hall; palace”), from Proto-Germanic *salaz, *salą (“house, room, hall”). More at sale.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A loft or upper chamber forming the private accommodation of the head of the household in a medieval hall; a garret room.
